name: parser
comment:
This library has a parser for HTML5 documents, that lets you parse HTML easily from a script or server side application:

import 'package:html5lib/parser.dart' show parse;
import 'package:html5lib/dom.dart';
main() {
  var document = parse(
      '<body>Hello world! <a href="www.html5rocks.com">HTML5 rocks!');
  print(document.outerHtml);
}

The resulting document you get back has a DOM-like API for easy tree traversal and manipulation.

getElementNameTuple.name: getElementNameTuple
getElementNameTuple.comment: Convenience function to get the pair of namespace and localName.

parse.name: parse
parse.comment:
Parse the html5lib/parser.parse.input html5 document into a tree. The html5lib/parser.parse.input can be a dart-core.String, dart-core<dart-core> of bytes or an html5lib/tokenizer.HtmlTokenizer.

If html5lib/parser.parse.input is not a html5lib/tokenizer.HtmlTokenizer, you can optionally specify the file's html5lib/parser.parse.encoding, which must be a string. If specified that encoding will be used regardless of any BOM or later declaration (such as in a meta element).

Set html5lib/parser.parse.generateSpans if you want to generate html5lib/source_maps-span.Spans, otherwise the html5lib/dom.Node.sourceSpan property will be null. When using html5lib/parser.parse.generateSpans you can additionally pass html5lib/parser.parse.sourceUrl to indicate where the html5lib/parser.parse.input was extracted from.

parseFragment.name: parseFragment
parseFragment.comment:
Parse the html5lib/parser.parseFragment.input html5 document fragment into a tree. The html5lib/parser.parseFragment.input can be a dart-core.String, dart-core<dart-core> of bytes or an html5lib/tokenizer.HtmlTokenizer. The html5lib/parser.parseFragment.container element can optionally be specified, otherwise it defaults to "div".

If html5lib/parser.parseFragment.input is not a html5lib/tokenizer.HtmlTokenizer, you can optionally specify the file's html5lib/parser.parseFragment.encoding, which must be a string. If specified, that encoding will be used, regardless of any BOM or later declaration (such as in a meta element).

Set html5lib/parser.parseFragment.generateSpans if you want to generate html5lib/source_maps-span.Spans, otherwise the html5lib/dom.Node.sourceSpan property will be null. When using html5lib/parser.parseFragment.generateSpans you can additionally pass html5lib/parser.parseFragment.sourceUrl to indicate where the html5lib/parser.parseFragment.input was extracted from.

class.name: HtmlParser
class.preview: Parser for HTML, which generates a tree structure from a stream of (possibly malformed) characters.

class.name: Phase
class.preview: Base class for helper object that implements each phase of processing.

packageIntro:
html5lib in Pure Dart

This is a pure Dart html5 parser. It's a port of html5lib from Python. Since it's 100% Dart you can use it safely from a script or server side app.

Eventually the parse tree API will be compatible with dart:html, so the same code will work on the client and the server.

Installation

Add this to your pubspec.yaml (or create it):

dependencies:
  html5lib: any

Then run the Pub Package Manager (comes with the Dart SDK):

pub install

Usage

Parsing HTML is easy!

import 'package:html5lib/parser.dart' show parse;
import 'package:html5lib/dom.dart';

main() {
  var document = parse(
      '<body>Hello world! <a href="www.html5rocks.com">HTML5 rocks!');
  print(document.outerHtml);
}

You can pass a String or list of bytes to parse. There's also parseFragment for parsing a document fragment, and HtmlParser if you want more low level control.

Running Tests

# From Dart SVN checkout
./tools/build.py -m release
./tools/test.py -m release html5lib
./tools/test.py -m release -r drt html5lib
